biogHist.abstract: King Edward Memorial Hospital (KEMH) has been Western Australia's principal public maternity and gynaelogical hospital since 1916. Many young women in out of home care were admitted there, and many babies were adopted from KEMH.

chronItem.event: Location - King Edward Memorial Hospital was opened by the government, with the main entrance on Bagot Road, Subiaco.

descriptiveNote.p: In 1916 the Government Receiving Depot relocated to West Perth and the Government Receiving Depot building became part of the King Edward Memorial Hospital.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Interviews with Clara Taylor and Dorothy Evelyn Wiley, nurses, State Library of Western Australia (1971)
Health Department, State of Western Australia (1984 - )

descriptiveNote.p: The Department of Health in Western Australia is responsible for all public hospital records created in WA. If you wish to find out if there is medical or personal information held about you from when you were a child, you must contact a Freedom of Information Officer.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Hospital [Public Hospitals] Records, Western Australia, Department of Health Western Australia (1894 - )
The Alexandra Home for Mothers and Babies (Inc) and Mothercraft Training School (1950 - 1956)

descriptiveNote.p: Mothers and babies could be transferred to The Alexandra Home for Mothers and Babies (Inc) and Mothercraft Training School from King Edward Memorial Hospital.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Beryl Grant interviewed by Christine Choo in the Forgotten Australians and Former Child Migrants oral history project (2011)

descriptiveNote.p: From 1936 babies whose mothers were in the Alexandra Home were born at the King Edward Memorial Hospital, and mothers and babies went to the Alexandra Home afterwards.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Ngal-a Mothercraft Home and Training Centre Inc (1956 - 1989)

descriptiveNote.p: Ngal-a Mothercraft Home and Training Centre Inc. (Ngala) sent all resident expectant mothers to King Edward Memorial Hospital (KEMH) for the birth of their babies in the years between 1956 and 1959. From 1959 to 1980 some women still had their babies at KEMH. Mothers and babies generally returned to Ngala after the birth, but from September 1959, babies could be sent from KEMH to Ngala without their mothers.

archref.abstract: 'Government Industrial School Subiaco, 1900' is a digital copy of an image included (p.12) in the Annual Report 1979 of the Department for Community Welfare. It is part of a history of the department, written to celebrate 150 years of European settlement in Western Australia.

archref.unitid: State Library of Western Australia Call No. 10028B/2766 and Record No. b2457399

archref.abstract: 'King Edward Memorial Hospital' is a digital copy of a photoprint of the entrance to the King Edward Memorial Hospital for Women in 1946. It is from the State Library of Western Australia's Government Photographer collection of online images.
